div.head: Ruskinʼs Boyhood Books
div.p: Colley's point that Foxe and Bunyan "went through a new and much wider period of fame and [were] interpreted in a far more aggressively patriotic fashion in the eighteenth century and after" (p. 25)
John Aiken and Anna Laetitia Barbauld, Evenings at Home

A copy with a Brantwood bookplate now at the Beinecke Library, Yale University, New Haven, Conn., may survive from Ruskin boyhood: Evenings at Home; / or the / Juvenile Budget Opened. / consisting of / a Variety of Miscellaneous Pieces / for the / Instruction and Amusement / of / Young Persons / by Dr. Aiken and Mrs. Barbauld / London / Printed and Published by J. F. Dove, / St. John Square.

The copy contains marginalia in Ruskinʼs mature hand, especially the pages containing the twenty‐first evening, which is connected with mineralogy (Viljoen, Ruskinʼs Backgrounds 8). Scrawls on the front endpaper may be Ruskinʼs from childhood: one of these scrawls Helen Gill Viljoen read as a “J”, and she declared this to be Ruskinʼs earliest extant signature (where does she say so? not in Backgrounds where she assigns earliest signature to Frank—maybe she thought better of it ).
See Anna Laetitia Barbauld, and, in connection with her influence, “The Needless Alarm”: Discusssion.
Maria Edgeworth, “Harry and Lucy Concluded”; although owned by Ruskin, may or may not have been his boyhood copy.
Maria Edgeworth, “Harry and Lucy Concluded” (Ruskinʼs copy)

A copy owned by Ruskin with a Brantwood bookplate was acquired by Sharp (Viljoen, Ruskinʼ Backgrounds, 7). Sharp gave his collection to Helen Gill Viljoen, who in turn, in dividing her collection between libraries, gave the Ruskin books in her possession to the Beinecke Library, Yale University, New Haven, Conn., where this copy of “Harry and Lucy Concluded” remains.
The copy is a first (1825) edition .

It is unclear whether this copy is the one that Ruskin used in childhood. The binding is tight and the pages clean, as compared with Ruskinʼs boyhood copy of Edgeworth, Frank, which and which contains marginalia in Ruskinʼs boyhood as well as mature hands. All the marginalia in Ruskinʼs “Harry and Lucy Concluded” is in Ruskinʼs mature hand; however, a crude geometrical drawing on the back endpaper of volume 4 may date from boyhood .

A copy owned by Ruskin with a Brantwood bookplate was acquired by Sharp (Viljoen, Ruskinʼs Backgrounds, 6). Sharp gave his collection to Helen Gill Viljoen, who in turn, in dividing her collection between libraries, gave the Ruskin books in her possession to the Beinecke Library, Yale University, New Haven, Conn., where this copy of Frank remains.
The copy is a first (1822) edition in three volumes .

The volumes, which have had heavy use , contain marginalia in the hand of one of his parents and in Ruskinʼs—both his boyhood and mature hands. The first volume has an inscription, “John Ruskin,” on the first flyleaf (recto), which Viljoen identifies as the hand of John James Ruskin; then, on a blank page which follows [i.e., the second flyleaf, recto], [is] Ruskinʼs earliest known signature , a pencilled one Ruskin apparently copied, in a most childish scrawl, from the name as written in ink by his Father (ibid.). Whether this is indeed Ruskin earliest extant signature cannot be determined, but the cursive script, which Ruskin did not generally adopt before , is indeed very labored.
The endpapers () of volume 1 also contain Frank drawing, untitled no. 1, and Frank drawing, untitled no. 2.
Daniel Defoe, Robinson Crusoe, allegedly a two–volume 1812 edition of The Life and Surprising Adventures of Robinson Crusoe (Ruskin Family Letters 150 n. 4).
